title: China’s economy records lowest growth since record-keeping began in 1992
text:
Its six per cent third-quarter growth is at the floor of Beijing’s target range of 6.0 to 6.5 per cent for 2019 overall. Lower investment, plunging exports to the U.S. and sluggish domestic consumption—particularly in the automotive market—are key factors in the slowdown. (New York Times)

Talking point: China is still the fastest-growing major economy in the world, but this outsized drop is bolstering worries of a global economic slowdown. It comes on the heels of yesterday’s somber report from the International Monetary Fund, which predicted a global economic growth rate of three per cent, the slowest since the 2008 financial crisis. China’s economy is certainly taking a hit from the trade war—foreign mergers and acquisitions fell 89 per cent in the first half of 2019—but domestic sluggishness is partly down to an uptick in financial regulation. Meanwhile, tech manufacturers spooked by U.S. tariffs are slowly moving their manufacturing facilities out of China—Samsung closed its last Chinese factory at the end of September.
